Merges specified annotation databases into one database and saves it into specified file.

member.name: T:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.BlendExtensions
member.summary: Contains blend filter extensions.

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.BlendExtensions.Blend(Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Byte}[0:,0:],Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Byte}[0:,0:],System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
The blending filter is able to blend two images using a homography matrix. A linear alpha gradient is used to smooth out differences between the two images, effectively blending them in two images. The gradient is computed considering the distance between the centers of the two images.
Homography matrix is set to identity.
Fill color is set to black with alpha set to 0 (all zeros).
member.param: The overlay image (also called the anchor).
A value indicating whether to blend using a linear gradient or just superimpose the two images with equal weights.
A value indicating whether only the alpha channel should be blended. This can be used together with a transparency mask to selectively blend only portions of the image.

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.BlendExtensions.Blend(Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Byte}[0:,0:],Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Byte}[0:,0:],Accord.Imaging.MatrixH,Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Bgra{System.Byte},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The blending filter is able to blend two images using a homography matrix. A linear alpha gradient is used to smooth out differences between the two images, effectively blending them in two images. The gradient is computed considering the distance between the centers of the two images.
member.param: The overlay image (also called the anchor).
Homography matrix used to map a image passed to the filter to the overlay image specified at filter creation.
The filling color used to fill blank spaces. The filling color will only be visible after the image is converted to 24bpp. The alpha channel will be used internally by the filter.
A value indicating whether to blend using a linear gradient or just superimpose the two images with equal weights.
A value indicating whether only the alpha channel should be blended. This can be used together with a transparency mask to selectively blend only portions of the image.

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.BlendExtensions.Blend(Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Bgr{System.Byte}[0:,0:],Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Bgr{System.Byte}[0:,0:],System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
The blending filter is able to blend two images using a homography matrix. A linear alpha gradient is used to smooth out differences between the two images, effectively blending them in two images. The gradient is computed considering the distance between the centers of the two images.
Homography matrix is set to identity.
Fill color is set to black with alpha set to 0 (all zeros).
member.param: The overlay image (also called the anchor).
A value indicating whether to blend using a linear gradient or just superimpose the two images with equal weights.
A value indicating whether only the alpha channel should be blended. This can be used together with a transparency mask to selectively blend only portions of the image.

The filling color used to fill blank spaces. The filling color will only be visible after the image is converted to 24bpp. The alpha channel will be used internally by the filter.

A value indicating whether only the alpha channel should be blended. This can be used together with a transparency mask to selectively blend only portions of the image.

member.summary: Gray-Level Difference Method (GLDM) extensions.

member.summary:
Gray-Level Difference Method (GLDM).
Computes an gray-level histogram of difference values between adjacent pixels in an image.
Accord.NET internal call. Please see: Gray-Level Difference Method for details.
member.param: Whether the maximum value of gray should be automatically computed from the image.
The direction at which the co-occurrence should be found.
member.returns: An histogram containing co-occurrences for every gray level in .

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.GoodFeaturesToTrackExtensions.GoodFeaturesToTrack(Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Single}[0:,0:],System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary:
Searches the image for the good features to track.
For each location a Hessian matrix is made and min eig-value is compared against threshold.
member.returns: List of locations that have eigen value larger than .

member.name: T:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Filters.GaborFilterExtensions
member.summary: Contains Gabor filter extensions.

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Filters.GaborFilterExtensions.GaborFilter(Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Byte}[0:,0:],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: (Accord .NET internal call) In image processing, a Gabor filter, named after Dennis Gabor, is a linear filter used for edge detection. Frequency and orientation representations of Gabor filters are similar to those of the human visual system, and they have been found to be particularly appropriate for texture representation and discrimination. In the spatial domain, a 2D Gabor filter is a Gaussian kernel function modulated by a sinusoidal plane wave. The Gabor filters are self-similar: all filters can be generated from one mother wavelet by dilation and rotation.
member.param: The Gaussian variance for the filter.
The orientation for the filter, in radians.
The aspect ratio for the filter.
The phase offset for the filter.

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Filters.GaborFilterExtensions.GaborFilter(Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Gray{System.Byte}[0:,0:],Accord.Imaging.Filters.GaborFilter)
member.summary: (Accord .NET internal call) In image processing, a Gabor filter, named after Dennis Gabor, is a linear filter used for edge detection. Frequency and orientation representations of Gabor filters are similar to those of the human visual system, and they have been found to be particularly appropriate for texture representation and discrimination. In the spatial domain, a 2D Gabor filter is a Gaussian kernel function modulated by a sinusoidal plane wave. The Gabor filters are self-similar: all filters can be generated from one mother wavelet by dilation and rotation.
member.param:
Gabor filter instance.
To avoid calculating Gabor every time use this function overload that receives instance.

member.name: T:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Moments.CentralMoments
member.summary: Central image moments.

remarks.para: In image processing, computer vision and related fields, an image moment is a certain particular weighted average (moment) of the image pixels' intensities, or a function of such moments, usually chosen to have some attractive property or interpretation.

Image moments are useful to describe objects after segmentation. Simple properties of the image which are found via image moments include area (or total intensity), its centroid, and information about its orientation.
The central moments can be used to find the location, center of mass and the dimensions of a given object within an image.

References:
Wikipedia contributors. "Image moment." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment

member.name: T:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.Moments.HuMoments
member.summary: Hu's set of invariant image moments.

remarks.para: In image processing, computer vision and related fields, an image moment is a certain particular weighted average (moment) of the image pixels' intensities, or a function of such moments, usually chosen to have some attractive property or interpretation.

Image moments are useful to describe objects after segmentation. Simple properties of the image which are found via image moments include area (or total intensity), its centroid, and information about its orientation.

Hu's set of invariant moments are invariant under translation, changes in scale, and also rotation. The first moment, , is analogous to the moment of inertia around the image's centroid, where the pixels' intensities are analogous to physical density. The last one, I7, is skew invariant, which enables it to distinguish mirror images of otherwise identical images.

References:
Wikipedia contributors. "Image moment." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment

member.summary: Raw image moments.

remarks.para: In image processing, computer vision and related fields, an image moment is a certain particular weighted average (moment) of the image pixels' intensities, or a function of such moments, usually chosen to have some attractive property or interpretation.

Image moments are useful to describe objects after segmentation. Simple properties of the image which are found via image moments include area (or total intensity), its centroid, and information about its orientation.
The raw moments are the most basic moments which can be computed from an image, and can then be further processed to achieve or even .

References:
Wikipedia contributors. "Image moment." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment

member.name: T:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.SmoothGaussianExtensions
member.summary: Gaussian smooth extensions.

member.name: M:Accord.Extensions.Imaging.SmoothGaussianExtensions.SmoothGaussian``1(``0[0:,0:],System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Smooths an image with Gaussian kernel.

summary.para: Smooths an image with Gaussian kernel.

Sigma calculation: When you want to cover an area below the Gaussian (centered on the mean) that covers 99.73% of the total area, you have to at least consider an interval of size 3*sigma, spread in both directions from the mean. In other words, using the parameter n of discrete cells for representing a Gaussian, we get 3*sigma <= n/2. We could reformulate this as 3*sigma <= (n/2-1) + (1+eps), where eps is a non-zero constant. Rearranging gives sigma <= 0.3334*(n/2-1) + (1+eps)/3. eps is set to: 1.4

member.summary: Calculates the image derivative by convolving the image with the appropriate kernel. Most often, the function is called with (xorder=1, yorder=0, aperture_size=3) or (xorder=0, yorder=1, aperture_size=3) to calculate first x- or y- image derivative.
member.param: Normalize kernel so the sum of all elements is 1.
